incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We detected an unusual high workload on us-west-1, we provisioned additional capacity to handle that load. We keep monitoring until scheduling delay is back to normal.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
We are currently investigating this issue.

Incident Period: 17th May 08:30 UTC - 20th May 16:00 UTC

The check result processing pipeline experienced increased latency, affecting checks with a frequency of 2 minutes and below. Checks with a frequency higher than 2 minutes were not affected. As a result of the increased latency, some high-frequency check runs were skipped due to being locked as still in progress. The issue was resolved as of 20th May 16:00 UTC. The pipeline is now operating normally, and we are implementing measures to prevent reoccurrence.

We apologize for any problems this may have caused. If you have any questions or concerns feel free to contact us via support@checklyhq.com

On May 1st, 11:15 pm UTC a buildup in memory usage in our check scheduling service started. It was caused by a user creating an extremely high number of client certificates for their checks. Over time, this caused the scheduler instances to crash until almost no checks could be scheduled from ~11 pm - 1 am UTC.

After an initial investigation, the on-call engineer decided to declare an incident and scale up the scheduling service to handle the high memory consumption. 

This partially restored service, but was not enough for full recovery. Memory usage was increasing very quickly and still causing crashes which caused some check runs to get lost. Check scheduling was still significantly impaired.

After investigating using logs, metrics, and events stored in our data lake, we were able to identify an account with an extremely high number of client certificates. The check scheduling service executed a database query through an implicit model dependency for every check run job, which loaded all certificates into memory, leading to high memory consumption. 

The incident was fully resolved when we enforced a hard limit of 10 certificates per account. The limit brought back the scheduling service' memory consumption to regular levels. After fixing the memory issues, we manually scaled up the platform to handle the build-up of queued check runs, and within ~30 minutes, the service returned to normal around 5:30 am UTC. 

How we move forward:

1. We have limited the amount of certificates users can create to 10 and the size to be max 50kb. Thereby preventing the same issue from happening a second time. 
2. We are adding tooling to investigate the heap usage of our NodeJS services so we can debug memory problems much faster if scaling up does not resolve them. Our current methods have proven insufficient under pressure in an incident situation. 
3. We are currently reviewing all APIs to make sure we have proper limits in place for other entities as well.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our May 2nd incident: https://stspg.io/t9r4032bzgq5

incidents.name: Increased check scheduling latency in us-east-1

incident_updates.body:
## Incident Summary: Elevated Browser Check Scheduling Latency in `us-east-1`

**Date:** March 28-29, 2024

### Overview

On March 28th from 23:40 UTC to March 29th at 1:43 UTC, Checkly experienced elevated browser check scheduling delay in the `us-east-1` region due to an unexpected surge in browser check runs, attributed to suspicious activity. This incident impacted approximately 37,600 browser and multistep checks, with the maximum delay reaching 44.5 minutes. API checks and heartbeat checks remained unaffected. All delayed checks were eventually processed. We didn’t detect any signs of false positives caused by this incident. 

### Root Cause

Suspicious activity within one customer’s accounts generated over 21,000 additional browser check runs in a short period of time, saturating the `us-east-1` region's capacity and causing the delays.

### Conclusion

We apologize for any inconvenience and assure you that all delayed checks were executed without any false positives. Checkly is committed to providing a reliable service and we are taking steps to enhance our resilience and security.

### Support

For questions or concerns, please contact [support@checklyhq.com](mailto:support@checklyhq.com). We value your trust and are here to help.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our March 29th incident: https://stspg.io/x6zpryy7xh4v

A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.

This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are currently investigating this issue.

We are currently modernizing and improving our runner infrastructure. During the rollout of the new sandbox runner, we shipped a broken deployment.

### Here is what happened:

1. We shipped a broken deployment, which resulted in false positives in a subset of checks.
2. Additionally, the rollback of the deployment failed, prolonging the incident.
3. The lack of proper internal communication about the system's state and rollback led to confusion and a prolonged response even more.

### The incident affected browser checks in two specific cases:

1. When using Twilio in any runtime - due to `TWILIO_ACCOUNT_SID` environment variable being improperly escaped. Affected check runs failed with an error message: `accountSid must start with AC`
2. Checks using `mocha` in runtimes 2022.02 and 2022.10 with Playwright. These checks failed with an error `Could not load reporter /checkly/functions/src/browser-check-common/src/mocha/reporter.js`: 

### Impact:

* A total of 10 customers were affected.
* A total of 120 browser check runs \(0.5%\) failed due to this incident.
* A total of 66 different checks were affected.
* The broken deployment was shipped at 15:30 and was rolled back at 16:10 UTC

We apologize for any problems this may have caused. **If you have any questions or concerns feel free to contact us via** [support@checklyhq.com](mailto:support@checklyhq.com)

incidents.name: Increased SMS delivery failure to Malaysia and U.S Verizon numbers

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

We are experiencing difficulties in delivering SMS alerts to Verizon U.S. numbers and to our customers in Malaysia. 
We are in contact with our SMS delivery provider to investigate and resolve this issue.

Due to a regression in the SSL certificate expiration alerting job, no alerts were sent for SSL certificates nearing expiration from December 12, 2023 to March 8, 2024. Affected customers have been directly notified, and the alerting is again working as expected.

Checkly’s SSL alerting is an older, rarely changed feature. Unlike other alerts, it does not go through our regular AlertingService, which is actively monitored through metrics like number of alerts sent or failed and similar. Instead, SSL alerting is based on a daily scheduled job that is monitored with a heartbeat check only. On Dec 12, 2023 - a regression was introduced to the SSL alerting job that caused the job to fail sending alerts, but without throwing an error. Since we only alerted based on job success until now, this was not caught by our monitoring and went unnoticed until March 5, 2024, when support reported a missing SSL alert to the engineering team. 

We are reviewing our entire monitoring for all Checkly alerting currently to make sure we do not have other such blindspots for older alerting features. SSL alerting will now be actively monitored and alerted by metrics such as number of alerts sent rather than just by tracking job success or failure. That way we can prevent such a high time to detect moving forward.

incidents.name: Intermittent networking issues in Frankfurt, London, Ireland over the last days

incident_updates.body:
We've discovered traces of intermittent networking issues in three European regions. The networking issues may have resulted in an increased check failure rate and partial check result loss for API checks. About 0.2% of checks runs in each of the 3 regions were affected. We are sorry for the inconvenience, please get in touch with support@checklyhq.com if you have any questions about your checks being affected.

eu-central-1 (Frankfurt): between 2024-03-07 18:30 and 2024-03-08 08:00 UTC
eu-west-2 (London): between  2024-03-09 00:50 and 2024-03-11 11:15 UTC 
eu-west-1 (Ireland): between  2024-03-09 19:50 and 2024-03-11 09:10 UTC

incidents.name: Increased latency and error rate in API

incident_updates.body:
In this incident our analytics database ran out of memory due to a misconfiguration. This caused issues for viewing the home dashboard and check overview pages, for private locations, and for heartbeat checks.

After analyzing our logs, we determined that the incident lasted from 2024-02-22 13:50 UTC to 2024-02-22 14:35 UTC. To address this issue, we’ve increased the capacity of our analytics database. We’ve also added additional alerting to detect increased memory usage in the analytics database before it affect users.

We apologize for any problems this may have caused. If you have any questions or concerns feel free to contact us via [support@checklyhq.com](mailto:support@checklyhq.com).
This incident has been resolved.
We are currently investigating this issue.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are seeing a small subset of checks fail. We are investigating.
SMS alerts were not delivered between 2:32 UTC and 2:44 UTC. We identified a faulty deployment and rolled it back.

incidents.name: Increased error rate of sending SMS alerts

incident_updates.body:
After a recent change in our SMS alerting service, we’ve introduced a regression which caused an increased error rate in SMS alert delivery to certain countries \(list of affected countries with country codes below\). After analysing our logs we determined that alerts were not correctly delivered between `2024-02-06 11:20 UTC` and `2024-02-08 09:00 UTC`. We’ve implemented a fix and improved the sensitivity of our alarms in the SMS service to prevent similar issues from happening in the future.  
  
We apologize for any problems this may have caused. If you have any questions or concerns feel free to contact us via [support@checklyhq.com](mailto:support@checklyhq.com) 

List affected countries, country codes

* Belgium: `+32`
* US: `+1`
* Brazil: `+55`
* Australia: `+61`
* Turkey: `+90`

incidents.name: Elevated error rate for check scheduling

incident_updates.body:
**Impact**: Partial unavailability of internal observability \(o11y\) stack

**Summary**: Today, on the 29th of January, between 15:19 UTC and 16:37 UTC, Checkly experienced a partial outage of the internal observability stack. This incident led to a loss of metrics and logs for our runtime environments.

**Customer Impact**: After an analysis of our database records, we concluded that customer checks remained unaffected during this period.  

**Root Cause**: The issue was traced back to a recently released version of a monitoring dependency that introduced a breaking change. This incident was amplified by the absence of version pinning in our configuration.

**Resolution and Prevention**: To address this issue and prevent similar occurrences in the future, we have implemented version pinning for our observability dependencies. This measure will ensure greater stability and control over our internal systems.

We apologize for any inconvenience caused and are committed to continuously improving our systems for a reliable user experience.

Checks were still run and alerts were still processed during this time period. This incident was caused by a performance issue storing check results in the database.

A faulty configuration change to our runner infrastructure was deployed at 2024-01-15 15:45 UTC. This led to an overall failure rate of 2.1% of all browser checks in that time frame. We rolled the change back at 2024-01-16 08:45 UTC.

incidents.name: Degraded Browser Checks runs in ap-southeast-2, eu-west-1, eu-west-3, ca-central-1 and sa-east-1

incident_updates.body:
What happened:

Our alerting informed us about a bug _causing autoscaling to fail scaling up containers for some runtime/region combinations:_

2023\.09 / eu-west-1

2022\.10 / eu-west-3

2022\.10 / ap-southeast-2

2022\.10 / ca-central-1

2022\.10 / sa-east-1

We deployed a hotfix that restored services during the incident preventing further regions from being affected and restoring service. 

How we will prevent this from happening:

Our monitoring alerted us through a side effect of the issue. The alert was triggered because of a high scheduling delay for checks. After fixing the bug, we added monitoring for failed ECS task starts. This will drastically lower the time to detect in the future and would have prevented downtime.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our October 10th incident: https://stspg.io/686y3mmx5rj5

From 11:05PM UTC to 11:50UTC no checks were run. The incident was triggered by a failover in a database used for check scheduling. The database was still functioning correctly, but the check scheduling service was incorrectly configured and did not gracefully handle the failover. This configuration issue has been resolved for the check scheduling service, and we will be testing our other services to make sure that similar incidents don’t occur again in the future.

incidents.name: Dashboard is stuck in a login loop

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
Our upstream provider fixed this issue, and we're monitoring the situation.
Our web application is not accessible due to a login error. We're currently investigating this issue.

A scheduled job saturated our database resources between 10:50 AM UTC to 11:03 AM UTC. During this timeframe :

- checks were not scheduled.
- alerts were not sent. 
- dashboard was not accessible.
- our public API was responding with 500 errors.

Affected components : 
- API
- Web Application
- Public Dashboards
- Check Scheduler
- Deployments
- Alerting

We quickly stopped the faulty job, and everything is operating normally.
A faulty deployment impaired the runner infrastructure between 06:15 (UTC) and 07:08 (UTC) which delayed a subset of check executions.
A fix has been deployed by our partner. Deployments should now be running as usual.
We are seeing degraded performance in our deployment triggers (Vercel) as a result of upstream provider.

A deployment introduced a bug where failing checks with the “_Double-check on failure_” feature enabled were not processed. This means we were not able to report check results and alert users during the incident only for failing checks with the _“Double-check on failure”_ feature enabled.

A fix has been deployed and we’re improving our monitoring around this part of our infrastructure.
